review.title: IK-PSO, PSO Inverse Kinematics Solver with Application to Biped Gait Generation
review.abstract: This paper describes a new approach allowing the generation of a simplified Biped gait. This approach combines a classical dynamic modeling with an inverse kinematics' solver based on particle swarm optimization, PSO. First, an inverted pendulum, IP, is used to obtain a simplified dynamic model of the robot and to compute the target position of a key point in biped locomotion, the Centre Of Mass, COM. The proposed algorithm, called IK-PSO, Inverse Kinematics PSO, returns and inverse kinematics solution corresponding to that COM respecting the joints constraints. In This paper the inertia weight PSO variant is used to generate a possible solution according to the stability based fitness function and a set of joints motions constraints. The method is applied with success to a leg motion generation. Since based on a pre-calculated COM, that satisfied the biped stability, the proposal allowed also to plan a walk with application on a small size biped robot.

metadata.title: IK-PSO, PSO Inverse Kinematics Solver with Application to Biped Gait Generation

sections.text: This approach combines a classical dynamic modeling with an inverse kinematics solver based on particle swarm optimization, PSO. First, an inverse pendulum, IP, is used to obtain a simplified dynamic model of the robot and to calculate the target position of a key point of bipedal locomotion, the mass center, COM. The proposed algorithm, called IK-PSO, inverse kinematics PSO, returns and inverse kinematics solution according to this COM, taking into account the joint constraints. In this essay, the variant of inertial weight PSO is used to generate a possible solution according to the stability-based fitness function and a series of motion restrictions for joints. The method is successfully applied to a leg movement generation. As it is based on a pre-calculated COM that fulfilled the two-legged stability, the proposal also allowed the planning of a walk with the application of two-legged constraints.

sections.heading: 3. IK-PSO, INVERSE KINEMATICS USING PSO
sections.text: Particle swarm optimization was proposed for motion generation and optimization; attempts to use the original PSO formulation to generate the gaits of a two-legged robot system [15] [16] [17]. In [15], a proposal was examined that uses the symmetrical characteristics of the two-legged gaits to operate a PSO that transfers leg motion characteristics from one to another. In [16], a random gait generator using classical PSO [11] was examined with a control of walking stability, the proposal was then matched with an agent-based architecture [17]. In [18], a PSO gait generator was inserted into a control flow using classical PID controllers. In this work, the PSO is examined as an alternative to ICT solvers. The proposed algorithm could be applied to any robotic system, while this paper focuses only on its use for two-legged robots.

sections.heading: 4.2 Robot Prototyping
sections.text: A robot kit is used here to validate the IK-PSO method [19]. For this purpose, the assembled robot has a design similar to the proposed simplified model, see Figure 7. In this assembled two-legged robot, a leg consists of two segments and a footprint. The joints are actuated by a servomotor, which includes its control with a built-in PID controller. Walking is achieved by generating a swivel motion of leg 1, while leg 2 is used to support the robot, and a swivel motion of leg 2, when leg 1 is the support. In our case, the following steps were performed during robot prototyping: First, we build a simple two-legged robot with only three degrees of freedom on each leg. Subsequently, the robot parameters, including segment size, servo masses were measured. Real robot movements were reported to the IK-PSO algorithm.

sections.heading: 5. DISCUSSION AND FURTHER WORKS
sections.text: The IK-PSO algorithm, Inverse Kinematics PSO, is based on a forward kinematic model, a specific formulation of the PSO, and a fitness function to provide the inverse kinematics solution of a robotic system. IK-PSO generates a series of solutions, each in a particle, then calculates the forward equivalent target position of a particular point, the COM for a walk, and returns the best one. The algorithm could solve any inverse kinematics problem while applying it here to the flywheel leg of a two-legged robot, before extending it to the global walkway, where a simplified inverse pendulum model is used to estimate the COM position. This position was then given to the IKSO to generate the required motion joints to create the required motion joints.
